text:
26:12

One, two, three, two, two, three

There's a whole lot of money that you gave me
I'd gladly empty my pockets right now
You'd parlay all that by triple
It's just that simple

Those days I'd gladly walk so long for you,
Although it seemed I crawled most of the way
After some time I felt like a cripple
It's just that simple

Last week I was thinking about traveling by land
And the time you remember we were by the lake
It wasn't even like we made a ripple
It's just that simple
In my head, the time didn't make a ripple
It's just that simple

text:
20:20
It's in my hair, it's on my clothes
It's in the river over the road
It's shining down, my angry star
Hanging off the hood of my car

I'm not going far
I'm not going far

It's coming down, they're coming up the shoulders
What have they found, I wonder if they know?
I'm in a bull black Chevy Nova
Silhouetted by the setting sun

This can't be undone
This can't be undone

If I'm the one with blood on my sofa
Blood in the sink, blood in the trunk
High at the wheel of a bull black Nova
Then I'm sorry as the setting sun

This can't be undone
Can't be outrun

It's in my head, there's blood in the sink
I can't calm down, I can't think
I keep calling, there's blood in the trunk
I can't calm down

Pick up
Pick up

text: Can’t even imagine what turned off the thumbs down people to this performance. I would challenge anyone to reinvent themselves the way Wilco can.  Writing a one hit wonder is a miracle in itself. Now imagine having Wilco’s amazing catalog of music and then waking up one day and saying “let’s do a killer all acoustic set” and actually pulling it off . Incredible talent all around.

text: I'm not old enough to have been there, in the moment, for early Wilco. That being said, how can I not appreciate the entire discography? When getting into a band, I'm a deep dive person... going from Uncle Tupelo, side projects of both past and current members, and even Son Volt just because Trace is an incredible album. Having listened to almost everything Wilco and related folks have to offer, this KEXP sessions (and mention to all the NPR sessions) are maybe Wilco's finest work. If nothing else, it's what turned me on to Wilco in 2015. Thanks KEXP!
author: Coy Moses

author: Maggie Osterberg

text:
I have loved Jeff and Jay from the Uncle Tupelo days and enjoy both Wilco and Sunvolt. But of all the lineups, this is the tightest group of talented musicians ever assembled.  And not just with Wilco.  I think any band.


I remember reading in the LA Weekly decades ago an article talking about how, at that time, U2 was the last "real band."  Meaning, the last of bands where the label put time into a band and developed them and stuck with them.  The point of the article was that it is so much easier to develop a one hit wonder/bubble gum garbage pop band, maximize revenue, cast them aside, and do it again so labels quit investing in bands with more depth and talent.  Sound familiar? Like some dumbass telling a band they can have their album back?  


I first saw Nels Cline play with Mike Watt at Slims in San Francisco on his Ballhog or Tugboat tour.  Nels was one of many guest performers but he stole the show.  Blew my mind when he joined Wilco.  Glenn is a master, John is so solid. Sansone and Jorgensen... Come on.  And these dudes can play ANYTHING. BTW, pat killed it on keyboards a couple of months ago (5/15/2019) with Mavis Staples at the Ryman.


Thank you Wilco.
author: pdledesma

text:
Anyone think that Wilco is the modern equivalent to The Band? I do accept that there are a ton of differences but ... it just struck me.


Love their songs - especially the slower quieter ones
author: Guy Francis

text: One of my good friends (who has very similar musical taste to me) said that I had to watch this performance, because it would introduce me to Wilco properly, and than I would be crazy about them. After watching the entire set, I gotta say ... I just don't get it. I understand that they're sound musicians, and I can tell that the sound engineer did one helluva job on this live set, buuuuuuut it just sounds like backyard folk music to me. It's the kind of stuff you might hear playing quietly in the background of a hipster coffee shop. More power to 'em, but I don't get the hype. NEXT!

author: Tim Schmidt Art

text: Because they seem like they are worthy of respect, I've been trying for ten years to find one good Wilco song.  It's like they are sincere and are competent technically and have the right influences but they don't have one compelling melody in their whole catalogue, and that isn't an exaggeration.  People who follow them are essentially musically challenged, (but not culturally), like people who listen to Creed or modern pop country radio.  - Good they've been able to tour and have some success.  They seem like nice guys.  - For those of you with no life like me tonight who are reading this listen to old rem or the replacements or tom petty or Big Star or Jeff Lynne.  It's like this but way better.
author: Endless Nameless

text: What a great performance.
author: Jason Bush

text: what a great mix!  Love Jeff's vocals.
author: kckrye

text: God this is incredible! Also made me appreciate Star Wars more when the songs are played like this. This is a band that doesn't stop innovating just because of success and age. But with that success and age comes a lot of letting go and having fun! This is just an infectious set. I think I'm going to listen to it like 40 times.
